race.name: Clarkes Gambit
race.tagline: Bushranger-country gravel with a tidal river crossing near Nelligen, Australia.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Australian coastal countryside. Moderate elevation with coastal scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Australian event. Coastal terrain with remote access, moderate costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Clarkes Gambit is a local event in NSW—coastal terrain with moderate elevation. The Australian coastal scenery is scenic, but the very small field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Australian coastal gravel race. Worth it for NSW/Australian riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to NSW—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Australian races: Gravel Gong, Dirty Gravel.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Nelligen has very limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Nelligen has very limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Australian coastal conditions require specific preparation.
Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: Steam Packet Hotel centralizes everything with 6:30 AM coffee and registration, but remote Nelligen location means 2.5 hours from Canberra Airport. Mike Israel notes organizers are "literally paddling crazy like a duck under stillwaters to keep you all safe, fed and watered" for 200 riders across the weekend.

length.explanation: Long course delivers 93km/1,925m Day 1, 56km/1,150m Day 2 for solid weekend volume. Organizers target 15-20 kph average speeds and require riders to "be at a good level of fitness to complete their chosen distance." Medium and short options scale appropriately without overwhelming newer riders. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Mike Israel describes "champagne gravel roads" on State Forest roads that are "mostly very smooth and a joy to ride" when dry. However, he warns "Please don't bring your roadie, even if you have 28mm tyres on it," indicating technical demands beyond smooth pavement despite the groomed surfaces. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 2026 long course features 1,925m Day 1 plus 1,150m Day 2 for 3,075m total climbing across the weekend. Starting near sea level at Nelligen means every meter is earned through State Forest roads, with past editions including "brutal 4km at 9%" climbs that define the challenge. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 64°F and lows of 44°F, with a 43% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 28 mph. Mike Israel acknowledges weather volatility: "We are aiming to stick almost entirely to State Forest roads that in the dry are mostly very smooth and a joy to ride. But a turn in the weather can bring on a dramatic change in conditions for the worse." NSW South Coast weather remains unpredictable for planning. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 10m above sea level in coastal Nelligen means altitude plays zero performance role. Even the climbs through state forests stay in low hundreds of meters. Sea-level fitness translates directly with no altitude considerations. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Named after the Clarke bushranger brothers who "rustled livestock, ambushed gold shipments and robbed traders from Braidwood to Bega." The event captures this with champagne gravel exploration and the signature tidal river crossing where riders wade "knee deep water for about 100m" hoisting bikes overhead.

prestige.explanation: Final round of the Bushranger Gravel Series sounds meaningful until you realize nobody outside NSW knows what that is. Zero notable winners mentioned, no pro field, no media coverage. Being on AusCycling's National Calendar means about as much as your participation trophy from junior cross.

race_quality.explanation: Organizers explicitly call it "not a race, but rather a social cycling experience designed to be enjoyed in small groups." Feed zones, mechanical support, and professional photography are included. The smaller field means personalized attention but limits competitive edge.

experience.explanation: Steam Packet Hotel provides the classic finish atmosphere with post-ride drinks and sunset views by the Clyde River. Car camping across from BIG4 Caravan Park creates the intended social overnighter experience, though the emphasis on "Type 1 Fun only" limits adventure intensity.

community.explanation: 2023 edition described as "Our biggest event ever" with approximately 200 riders and volunteer support from Milton Ulladulla Cyclists. The social format encourages small ability-matched groups, with family discounts and group rates fostering inclusive participation over competitive intensity.

field_depth.explanation: 15-20 kph target speeds and requirements for "reasonable mechanical know how" for basic repairs suggest recreational rather than competitive fields. The explicit positioning as "not a race" and social group riding format indicates limited competitive depth despite 200-rider participation. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: $179 early bird includes professional ReadyAimMedia photography, feed zones, mechanical support, commemorative patches, and goodie bags. Group discounts (10% for 10+ riders) and family pricing enhance value, with "Bike Packing not required" reducing gear investment compared to typical overnighters.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-100 AUD. Remote Nelligen location adds fuel costs from major airports. E-bikes welcome, reducing gear transport needs. Mechanical skills required for "punctures, ripped tyres, broken chains" suggests self-sufficiency expectations. Car camping setup helps control accommodation costs. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M
primary.why: Mixed-terrain specialist. Balanced grip and speed for variable conditions.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Graveleur's Ultimate Gravel Ride: Clarkes Gambit Day 1 Adventure!
videos.description:
Join us on the first day of the thrilling Graveleur's Clarkes Gambit, a two-day gravel cycling event in Nelligen, NSW. This video captures the essence of the adventure - from challenging climbs and scenic gravel paths to the camaraderie among cyclists. Experience the excitement, the challenges, and the sheer joy of participating in this unique event. Whether you're a seasoned cyclist or new to gravel riding, this video offers a glimpse into the world of endurance cycling and the beauty of Nelligen's landscapes. Don't forget to like, share, and subscribe for more cycling adventures to join our community of cycling enthusiasts!

Headed off to ride my first 2 day event. Graveleur put on Clarkes Gambit in Nelligen, NSW. It was a blast, an ass kicker and overall a great event. The weather was fantastic. The routes both beautiful and brutal. I loved it. Day 1 saw a route change that seemingly added more elevation than prescribed. Needless to say, I was nervous about day 2! 

--------------------- Links from this video ----------------------
https://graveleur.cc/event/clarkes-gambit-2023/

----------------------------- Music -----------------------------
Artist: MOLIFE
Song: East Coast

---------------------------- My Gear ----------------------------

#GravelCycling, #AdventureRide, #Graveleur

videos.title: Graveleur's Clarkes Gambit: The Ultimate 2 Day Gravel Ride Challenge!
videos.description:
Embark on the second day of Graveleur's Clarkes Gambit, an intense gravel cycling event in Nelligen, NSW. Day 2 ups the ante with more challenging climbs, breathtaking rolling hills, and the unyielding spirit of adventure. This video takes you through the highs and lows of enduring one of the most exhilarating gravel rides, capturing the essence of determination and the beauty of the Australian landscape. Whether you're an experienced cyclist or just love the thrill of a challenging ride, this video is a testament to the joys and trials of endurance cycling. Join us on this journey, and don't forget to like, share, and subscribe for more cycling adventures. Be part of our cycling community and share your own experiences with us!

Headed off to ride my first 2 day event. Graveleur put on Clarkes Gambit in Nelligen, NSW. It was a blast, an ass kicker and overall a great event. The weather was fantastic. The routes both beautiful and brutal. I loved it. Day 2 was EPIC! the climbing the descents the heat. WahWahWeWah. All just full on. I was feeling strong and just kept the legs moving. Nothing was going to get in the way. Highlights? No CRAMPS! none. So this mystery is still that. A mystery. Let hope the new fuel is helping. 

--------------------- Links from this video ----------------------
Event: https://graveleur.cc/event/clarkes-gambit-2023/
Camping: https://www.hipcamp.com/en-US/land/new-south-wales-nello-campsite-pw1h8rj8/sites/493144?siteId=493144&adults=1&children=0
Articles/Book: https://medium.com/the-ivory-tower-paradox
Podcast: https://www.unplugyourself.net/

videos.curation_reason: First-person race recap of Day 2 featuring the challenging 7-8km climbs and rolling hills section.

videos.title: Maxxis Geared up for Graveleur's 2025 Final Bushranger Gravel Series with Clarkes Gambit
videos.description:
Maxxis x Graveleur – Clarke’s Gambit, Nelligen NSW

What a weekend! Maxxis hit the South Coast for Round 3 of the Graveleur Bush Ranger Gravel Series, with the Steam Packet Hotel setting the perfect backdrop.
Big shoutout to Steve from Cessnock Bicycle Company for tyre fitments, rider support, and running the mid-race aid station, absolute legend!

Saturday delivered hot, dusty, tough conditions, but the waist-deep river crossing gave everyone the cooldown they needed. Over 180 riders smashed out the 35 km, 55 km, and 100 km courses before rolling into the beer garden for a cold one under the Maxxis arch.

We wrapped up with podium prizes, fresh Maxxis Gravel tyres, and Sunday’s social ride to finish the weekend strong.
Huge thanks to the Graveleur crew for another epic event stoked to be part of this growing gravel community.

quotes.text: It rained all night so it is a bit wet not too cold... that rain last night definitely probably helped with kind of dust we'll receive but I intend to be dirty we got River Crossings and all sorts.
We just did that massive River Crossing which was hectic full wet feet prob... you can see where the lightest of a front suspension even like a few centimeters would help through some of these bits.
It's an 8K climb today... the long enduring climbs... we're only 38k in yeah oh boy this shit's going to get real.
